The Ground of Joy, Chapter 1: The Ground of Joy
Thus have I heard:

Once the Buddha was in the palace of the Heaven of Freely Partaking of Others' Emanations, in the Mani Jewel Hall, together with a great assembly of bodhisattvas, all of whom were irreversible from supreme, perfect enlightenment, having come together from other world systems.

These bodhisattvas had attained mastery over all the wisdom practices of bodhisattvas, had entered into the wisdom of the tathÄgatas, were skilled in teaching and transforming all worldly realms, and at all times universally manifested spiritual powers and other events.

In every moment of thought, they were able to accomplish and perfect all the vows of bodhisattvas, and in all worlds, throughout all kalpas and all lands, they constantly cultivated the practices of bodhisattvas.

They were replete with all the merit and wisdom of bodhisattvas, inexhaustible, able to benefit all, able to reach the other shore of the wisdom and skillful means of all bodhisattvas, able to show sentient beings the doors of birth and death and nirvana.

They did not cut off any of the practices of bodhisattvas, skillfully traversing the dhyanas, liberations, samadhis, supernormal knowledge, and wisdom of all bodhisattvas, well able to manifest them. They had all attained the effortless spiritual powers of all bodhisattvas, and in a single thought were able to reach the great assemblies of buddhas in the ten directions, exhorting, requesting, and upholding the wheel of the Dharma.
They always made great offerings to the buddhas, always able to cultivate the practices of all great bodhisattvas.
Their bodies universally manifested in immeasurable worlds;
Their voices were universally heard, reaching everywhere;
Their minds penetrated and clearly saw all bodhisattvas in the three times.
They were replete with the cultivation of all merits and virtues.
Thus, the merits of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are immeasurable and boundless, and cannot be fully described even in countless eons.

Moreover, Vajra Treasury!

You should explain the distinctions of this Dharma door, namely, by the spiritual power of the buddhas, because you are able to bear the spiritual power of the TathÄgata, because of the purity of your own roots of goodness, because of the nature of pure Dharma-nature, because of the nature of benefiting sentient beings, because of enabling sentient beings to attain the pure Dharma body and wisdom body, because of attaining the prediction of Buddhahood from all buddhas, because of attaining the highest and greatest body in all worlds, because of transcending all worldly paths, and because of the purity of supramundane roots of goodness.

At that time, the Buddhas of the ten directions revealed to Vajra Treasury the true and unsurpassed Buddha body, and bestowed unobstructed eloquence, the ability to skillfully discriminate and have pure wisdom, the ability to remember well and not forget, the ability to make good decisions, the ability to reach all places of wisdom, the indestructible power of the Buddhas, the fearlessness and courage of the Buddhas, the unobstructed wisdom of the Buddhas to discriminate and skillfully open the Dharma gates, and the supreme physical, verbal, and mental actions of all Buddhas.
Why is it so?

It is because of attaining the method of the Bodhisattva's great wisdom light samadhi, also because of the power of the Bodhisattva's original vows, the purity of his mind, the clarity of his wisdom, the good accumulation of auxiliary practices, the good cultivation of the fundamental practices, the ability to uphold immeasurable mindfulness, the pure light of faith and understanding, the nondiscriminatory attainment of the dharani gate, and the good sealing of the Dharma nature with the seal of wisdom.
At that time, the Buddhas of the ten directions all extended their right hands to pat Vajra Treasury Bodhisattva on the head.
Vajra Treasury Bodhisattva then arose from samÄdhi. Having arisen, he addressed the bodhisattvas, saying:
All Buddha's disciples!

These matters of the bodhisattvas are all well-determined by themselves, without transgression, without discrimination, pure and clear, vast like the nature of phenomena, ultimately like space, universally covering all the Buddha-lands and sentient beings in the ten directions, in order to save and liberate all worldly beings, and are protected by the spiritual powers of all Buddhas.
Why is it so?
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas enter the stage of wisdom of the Buddhas of the past, and also enter the stage of wisdom of the Buddhas of the future and present.
All Buddha's disciples!
What are the stages of wisdom of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas?
All Buddha's disciples!
There are ten stages of wisdom for the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.
The Buddhas of the past, present, and future have already taught, are teaching, and will teach for the sake of this ground, and I am teaching in the same way.
What are the ten?

The first is called the Ground of Joy, the second is called the Ground of Purity, the third is called the Ground of Radiance, the fourth is called the Ground of Fiery Adornment, the fifth is called the Ground of Hard to Conquer, the sixth is called the Ground of Presence, the seventh is called the Ground of Far-reaching, the eighth is called the Ground of Immovability, the ninth is called the Ground of Excellent Wisdom, and the tenth is called the Ground of Dharma-cloud.
Buddha's disciples!
The Buddhas of the three times have already taught, are teaching, and will teach these ten grounds. I do not see any Buddha-land where they do not teach the ten grounds of the bodhisattvas.
Why is this?
These ten grounds are the supreme and wondrous path of the bodhisattvas, the supreme bright and pure Dharma door, namely the discernment of the ten abodes.
Buddha's disciples!
This matter is inconceivable, namely the wisdom of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva in accordance with the grounds.
At that time, Vajra Treasury Bodhisattva MahÄsattva, having spoken the names of the ten grounds of the bodhisattvas, fell silent and did not further explain the meaning.
At that time, the assembly of all bodhisattvas, having heard the names of the ten grounds of the bodhisattvas, all yearned to hear the explanation and each had this thought:
For what causes and conditions did Vajra Treasury Bodhisattva speak the names of the ten grounds of the bodhisattvas and then fall silent, not further explaining?

At that time, within the great assembly of bodhisattvas there was a bodhisattva mahÄsattva named Liberation Moon, who knew the thoughts in the minds of the bodhisattvas and asked Vajra Treasury Bodhisattva in verse:
Pure wisdom, mindful and wise one!
Why, having spoken the names of the bodhisattvas' grounds, do you fall silent and not explain further?
Now the minds of the great bodhisattvas are all filled with doubt:
Why speak these names but not expound their meaning?
The great wise bodhisattvas all wish to listen and hear,
The meaning of these grounds, please explain and analyze them.
This assembly of bodhisattvas is pure, without defilement,
Abiding in the solid Dharma, endowed with wisdom and merit,
All with a respectful mind, looking up to you,
Wishing to hear what is said, like thirsting for sweet dew.
The bodhisattva Vajra Treasury, having heard this matter,
Wishing to delight the great assembly, then spoke a verse, saying:
The practices of the bodhisattvas are the foremost, difficult to conceive,
Analyzing these grounds is the root of the buddhas.
Subtle and extremely difficult to see, beyond the capacity of the mind,
Emerging from the Buddha's wisdom, if heard, one will be confused and submerged.
Upholding the mind like vajra, deeply believing in the Buddha's wisdom,
Taking it as the foremost and wondrous, the mind has no doubts or difficulties,
Far removed from the mind that conceives of a self, and the ground of mental activity,
Such bodhisattvas are then able to listen and receive.
The knowledge of quiescent extinction and freedom from defilements is extremely difficult to explain in detail,
Like painting in the sky, like grasping at the wind in space.
I think of the Buddha's wisdom, which is foremost and inconceivable,
Few beings are able to believe it, therefore I remain silent.
Bodhisattva Moon of Liberation, having heard this, said to Bodhisattva Vajra Treasury:
Buddha's disciple!

This great assembly of bodhisattvas has a pure and profound mind, skillfully practices the bodhisattva path, skillfully accumulates the factors that assist the path, is well able to make offerings and respectfully serve the buddhas, has planted many wholesome roots with immeasurable buddhas, has accomplished immeasurable profound and thick merits, is free from delusion, doubt, and regret, is without attachment and all bonds, has a profound mind of faith and understanding, abides unmoved, and in this Dharma does not follow the teachings of others.
Therefore, Buddha's disciples!
You should rely on the Buddha's power to expound this meaning. These bodhisattvas are all able to realize and know this profound Dharma.
At that time, Vimukticandra, wanting to reiterate this meaning, spoke in verse, saying:
Please explain the peaceful Dharma, the unsurpassed practice of the bodhisattvas,
And distinguish the various stages, causing wisdom to be pure.
The pure and stainless wisdom of the assembly abides in profound faith and understanding,
And in the immeasurable buddhas realizes and knows the meaning of the ten stages.
At that time, Vajra Treasury Bodhisattva said:
Buddha's disciple!

Although this great assembly is all pure, free from delusion, doubt, and regret, and does not follow the teachings of others in this matter, the others who delight in the lesser Dharma, hearing this extremely profound and inconceivable matter, may give rise to doubt and regret. These people will for a long time experience various harms. I have compassion for them and therefore remain silent.
At that time, Vajra Treasury Bodhisattva, wanting to clarify this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
Although this assembly is pure, with profound wisdom and free from doubt and regret,
Their minds have already been determined, and they no longer follow the teachings of others,
Unmoving like Mount Sumeru, unconfused like the great ocean.
The others, who have not practiced for a long time, whose wisdom is not yet clear,
Following consciousness and not wisdom, give rise to doubt and regret upon hearing it.
I do not speak out of compassion for them, as they are about to fall into evil destinies.
Bodhisattva Vimukti-candra said:
Buddha's disciple!
I wish you would skillfully discern and explain this inconceivable Dharma and the matters that the Buddha has in mind, making it easy for people to believe and understand, by the Buddha's power.
Why is this?

Because the meaning of the ten grounds is well-spoken, and the Dharma of the Buddhas of the ten directions should protect and think of it. All bodhisattvas protect this matter and diligently practice with vigor.
Why is this?
Because this is the supreme practice of bodhisattvas, leading them to attain all the Buddhadharmas.
It is like all the scriptures being included in the first chapter, with the first chapter as the basis, and not a single character not included in the first chapter.
In the same way, Buddha's disciple!
The ten grounds are the fundamental basis of all the Buddhadharmas. Bodhisattvas who fully practice these ten grounds can attain omniscience.
Therefore, Buddha's disciple!
I wish you would explain this meaning.
May the Buddhas protect and think of it, bestow their spiritual power, cause people to believe and accept it, and make it indestructible.
At that time, the Bodhisattva Vimukti-candra, wishing to elucidate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
Excellent! Son of wisdom!
Endowed with pure conduct,
Please explain the practices of the ten grounds and the dharmas entered in the ten grounds,
So that one may attain perfect wisdom and accomplish enlightenment.
All the Buddhas in the ten directions, the most honored among humans,
All together protect and think of you, explaining the meaning of the ten grounds.
The ten grounds are the fundamental, known as the abode of wisdom,
And also the ultimate path, the immeasurable Dharma aggregate of the Buddhas.
Just as all written characters are contained in the initial chapter,
The wisdom and merits of the Buddhas have the ten grounds as their foundation.
At that time, the Bodhisattvas spoke a verse in unison, requesting Vajra Treasury Bodhisattva, saying:
Supremely wonderful person of wisdom!
Delighting in speaking immeasurably, with virtues as heavy as a mountain king, compassionately explaining the ten grounds.
Precepts, mindfulness, and wisdom are pure, explaining the meaning of the ten grounds,
The root of the ten powers, the fundamental practice of unobstructed wisdom.
The merit of precepts, concentration, and wisdom, gathered in your mind,
Arrogance and all wrong views, all have been extinguished.
This assembly has no doubts, only wishing to hear the good explanation,
Like one thirsty thinking of water, like one hungry thinking of delicious food,
Like one sick thinking of a good doctor, like a bee wanting to eat honey,
We are also like this, hearing the taste of the nectar-like Dharma.
Therefore, with a vast intention, I wish you would open the door of the first ground,
Up to the tenth ground, please explain it in order for me.

At that time, Vajra Treasury Bodhisattva observed the ten directions, wishing to increase the faith and respect of the great assembly, and spoke a verse, saying:
The path of the holy lord buddhas is subtle and extremely difficult to understand,
Not attained through thought or speculation, only the domain of the wise.
Its nature, from the beginning, is tranquil, without arising or ceasing;
From the beginning, it is empty, eliminating all suffering and distress;
Far removed from the various destinies, equal to the characteristics of nirvana.
Without middle or end, not spoken by words,
Transcending the three times, its characteristics are like empty space.
The place where the buddhas practice is pure, profound, and quiescent,
Difficult to reach with words;
The stages of the earth are also like this, difficult to explain even in words, let alone demonstrate to others.
The wisdom of the buddhas is apart from the path of the mental functions,
Inconceivable, not having the aggregates, sense bases, or elements,
Only knowable through wisdom, not within the reach of consciousness.
Like a trace in the sky difficult to describe, how can its characteristics be shown?
The meaning of the ten stages is like this, not known by the mind of the boundless.
Although this matter is difficult, by generating the vow and practicing compassion,
Gradually perfecting the stages, not within the reach of the mind.
Such are the practices of the stages, subtle and extremely difficult to see,
Not knowable by the mind, one should explain by relying on the Buddha's power.
You should all respectfully listen with a single mind,
The practices of the stages entering each other, cultivating the methods of leaving the world.
Even if one were to speak for countless millions of eons, it would be impossible to exhaust,
Now I will briefly explain the truth, its meaning is without remainder.
Wait with a single mind of respect, now relying on the Buddha's power I will speak,
The great sound sings of causes and analogies, the meaning and names are not contradictory.
The Buddha's spiritual power is immeasurable, now it is all in my body,
What I speak of is like a single drop in the great ocean.
After Vajra Treasury Bodhisattva spoke this verse, he addressed the great assembly, saying:
Disciples of the Buddha!
If sentient beings thickly accumulate good roots, cultivate good practices, well gather the methods that assist the path, make offerings
to the Buddhas, accumulate all pure dharmas, are protected by good and wise advisors, enter the profound and vast
a mind of faith and joy in the great Dharma, a mind that often turns to compassion, and a fondness for seeking the wisdom of the Buddha.
Such sentient beings are able to give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment, in order to attain
omniscience, in order to attain the ten powers, in order to attain great fearlessness,
in order to attain the complete Buddha Dharma, in order to save all worlds, in order to purify the mind of great compassion,
in order to turn towards the unobstructed cognition of the ten directions without remainder, in order to purify all Buddha lands without remainder,

in order to know the events of the three times in a single thought, and in order to freely turn the great Dharma wheel and extensively manifest the spiritual powers of the Buddha. The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas give rise to such a mind.
O Buddha-sons!

This mind takes great compassion as the foremost, with wisdom as the superior, protected by skillful means, with a sincere and profound mind that is pure and sincere, its extent equal to the power of the Buddha, well able to measure the power of sentient beings and the power of the Buddha, heading towards unobstructed cognition and in accordance with natural cognition, able to receive all the Buddha's teachings, to teach and transform with wisdom, vast like the nature of phenomena, ultimate like space, extending to the end of the future.
Buddha's disciples!

When the bodhisattva gives rise to such a mind, he immediately transcends the stage of ordinary beings, enters the stage of bodhisattvas, is born in the Buddha's family, with a lineage that is beyond reproach, transcends all worldly paths, enters the supramundane path, abides in the bodhisattva's teachings, is counted among the bodhisattvas, enters the lineage of the tathÄgatas of the three times, and definitely ultimately attains supreme perfect enlightenment.
The bodhisattva who abides in such dharmas is called one who abides in the stage of joy, because he abides in unshakable dharmas.
Buddha's disciples!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas dwelling in this ground of joy have much joy, much faith, much purity, much leaping and delight, much pliancy, and much endurance. They do not like disputes, do not like to disturb sentient beings, and do not like to be angry or resentful.
Buddha's disciples!

The bodhisattvas dwelling in this ground of joy give rise to a joyful mind by recollecting the buddhas, give rise to a joyful mind by recollecting the buddhas' teachings, give rise to a joyful mind by recollecting the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, give rise to a joyful mind by recollecting the practices of the bodhisattvas, give rise to a joyful mind by recollecting the pure characteristics of the perfections, give rise to a joyful mind by recollecting the superiority of the bodhisattvas' company, give rise to a joyful mind by recollecting the indestructibility of the bodhisattvas' powers, give rise to a joyful mind by recollecting the buddhas' teaching methods, give rise to a joyful mind by recollecting their ability to benefit sentient beings, and give rise to a joyful mind by recollecting the wisdom and skillful means that all buddhas and bodhisattvas enter.
Buddha-sons!
The bodhisattva further thinks like this:

'I turn away from all worldly realms and give rise to a joyful mind. I enter into the equality of all Buddhas and give rise to a joyful mind. I am far removed from the stage of ordinary beings and give rise to a joyful mind. I am close to the stage of wisdom and give rise to a joyful mind. I cut off all evil destinies and give rise to a joyful mind. I become a support for all sentient beings and give rise to a joyful mind. I am close to seeing all Buddhas and give rise to a joyful mind. I am born in the realm of all Buddhas and give rise to a joyful mind. I enter the ranks of all bodhisattvas and give rise to a joyful mind. I am free from all fear, terror, and horripilation and give rise to a joyful mind.'
Why is it so?

This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva attains the ground of joy and is immediately free from all fears, namely, the fear of not surviving, the fear of bad reputation, the fear of death, the fear of falling into evil destinies, and the fear of the majestic virtue of the great assembly. He is free from all such fears.
Why is it so?
Because this bodhisattva is free from the notion of self, he does not even crave his own body, let alone the things he uses.
Therefore, he has no fear of not being able to live.
His mind does not hope for offerings and respect - that he should make offerings to sentient beings and provide for their needs - therefore, he has no fear of a bad reputation.
Free from the views of self and the notion of non-self, he has no fear of death.
Moreover, he thinks like this:
'After my death, I will certainly not be separated from the buddhas and bodhisattvas.
' Therefore, he has no fear of falling into evil paths.
'My aspirations and delights are unequaled, let alone being superior.
' Therefore, he has no fear of the majestic virtue of the great assembly.
Buddha's disciples!
In this way, the bodhisattva is free from all fears, horripilation, and other such things.
Buddha's disciples!
This bodhisattva, with great compassion as the foremost, with a profound and vast mind, and with firm resolve, further diligently cultivates all wholesome roots, namely:
With superior faith, they often cultivate a pure mind and a mind of understanding, and purify their minds with faith.
They give rise to a compassionate mind, accomplish great kindness, and are not weary in mind. They adorn themselves with shame and remorse, and accomplish patience and gentleness.
They respectfully follow the teachings of the Buddhas, and with faith and respect, they constantly cultivate wholesome roots day and night without weariness;
They draw close to good and virtuous friends, always delight in the Dharma, and seek much learning without weariness.

They contemplate the Dharma as it is, and contemplate correctly, without being attached to the mind, without seeking gain, fame, reputation, or any material things. Their minds are free from stinginess, and they always give rise to a true mind without being content.

They delight in the stage of omniscience, and always wish to attain the powers, fearlessness, and unique qualities of the Buddhas. They seek to assist the Dharma of the perfections and are free from flattery and deceit.
As they speak, they are able to practice, and always speak truthfully. They do not defile the Buddha's family, do not abandon the precepts of the bodhisattva training, and give rise to omniscience.

The mind is unmoving like a great mountain king, not delighting in any worldly matters, accomplishing supramundane wholesome roots, gathering the factors of enlightenment without being content, always seeking the supreme among supreme paths.
Buddha's disciples!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who accomplish such purifying practices of the grounds are said to abide in the bodhisattva's ground of joy.
Bodhisattvas who abide in this way in the ground of joy give rise to great vows and give rise to a mind of certainty, namely:

I shall make offerings to all buddhas without exception, making offerings with all offering implements according to my wishes, with a mind of pure understanding, giving rise to such great vows, vast like the nature of phenomena, ultimate like space, extending to the end of the future, making offerings to all buddhas in all kalpas without rest, with great offering implements.

Moreover, all the sutras and Dharma spoken by all Buddhas are completely upheld, in order to embrace the supreme, perfect enlightenment of all Buddhas. In accordance with the teachings of all Buddhas, all the Dharma of the Buddhas is well protected. Giving rise to such great vows, vast like the nature of Dharma, ultimate like space, exhausting the future, exhausting all protection of the Dharma of all Buddhas throughout all kalpas, without rest.

Moreover, in all worlds, all Buddhas descend from Tuá¹£ita Heaven into the womb, and while in the womb, at the time of birth, at the time of leaving home, at the time of attaining Buddhahood, they should all be requested to turn the great Dharma wheel and demonstrate entering great nirvana.

At that time, I went to make offerings to all of them, taking the Dharma as the foremost, turning in the three periods of time, giving rise to such a great vow, vast like the nature of phenomena, ultimate like space, exhausting the future, exhausting all kalpas, welcoming and making offerings to all Buddhas, without rest.

Moreover, all the practices of Bodhisattvas are vast, lofty, immeasurable, indestructible, and without discrimination. They are embraced by the perfections and purified by the stages, giving rise to various auxiliary practices. With characteristics and without characteristics, the path has formation and destruction;

All the practices, stages, and perfections of Bodhisattvas are originally practiced to transform and cause them to accept and practice, enabling the mind to grow. Giving rise to such a great vow, vast like the nature of phenomena, ultimate like space, exhausting the future, exhausting all kalpas, within the practices of Bodhisattvas, using the Dharma to transform and mature sentient beings, without rest.

Furthermore, all sentient beings, whether with form or formless, with thought or without thought, neither with thought nor without thought, born from eggs, wombs, moisture, or by transformation, bound to the three realms and entering the six destinies, in all places of birth, are included in name and form. In order to teach and transform all sentient beings, to cut off all worldly paths, to cause them to abide in the Buddha's teachings, and to gather all wisdom without remainder, one gives rise to such great vows, vast like the nature of phenomena, ultimate like space, exhausting future limits and all kalpas, teaching and transforming all sentient beings without rest.

Furthermore, all worlds, whether vast or narrow, extremely high, immeasurable, indistinguishable, immovable, indescribable as coarse or fine, upright or inverted, with the head facing the feet or the feet facing the head, flat or round or square;

In this way, they enter the world, with wisdom like the net of Indra, manifesting the distinctions of the sutras and illusions, and thus directly know the distinctions of the worlds in the ten directions.
They give rise to such great vows, vast like the nature of phenomena, ultimate like space, exhausting future kalpas and all worlds, directly knowing them without rest.

Furthermore, they cause all buddha lands to enter one buddha land, and one buddha land to enter all buddha lands. Each buddha land has immeasurable radiant adornments, free from defilements, replete with pure paths, filled with immeasurable wise beings, always having the great spiritual powers of the buddhas, manifesting according to the minds of beings. They give rise to such great vows, vast like the nature of phenomena, ultimate like space, exhausting the future and all kalpas, purifying such lands without rest.

Moreover, all bodhisattvas have the same mind and study together, gathering all wholesome [activities] without resentment or jealousy, focusing on one thing with an equal mind, harmoniously united, always inseparable.
They are able to manifest the Buddha's body at will, and in their own minds they can fully understand the spiritual powers and wisdom of all Buddhas.

They always attain spiritual powers according to their wishes, and are able to travel to all lands, manifesting their physical forms in all Buddha assemblies. They are born in all places of birth, possessing such inconceivable great wisdom and fulfilling the bodhisattva practices.
They give rise to such great vows, vast like the nature of phenomena and ultimate like space, practicing this path of great wisdom throughout the future, without rest.

Furthermore, riding the wheel of non-retrogression, practicing all the bodhisattva paths, with body, speech, and mind, all actions are not in vain. Sentient beings who see me will definitely attain the Buddha's teachings, hearing my voice will immediately attain true wisdom, and those who see me will rejoice in their hearts, leaving all afflictions, like the great medicine king.

In order to attain such a mind, practicing the bodhisattva path, making such vast vows, vast as the nature of phenomena, ultimate as space, exhausting future kalpas, practicing the path of non-retrogression, all actions not in vain, without rest.

Furthermore, attaining supreme perfect enlightenment in all worlds, demonstrating in a single hair-tip entering the womb, leaving home, sitting at the site of enlightenment, attaining Buddhahood, turning the wheel of Dharma, liberating sentient beings, and demonstrating great nirvana.

Manifesting the great spiritual powers and wisdom of the TathÄgatas, according to the beings to be liberated, moment by moment attaining Buddhahood, liberating sentient beings, and extinguishing suffering and distress, knowing that all phenomena are characterized by nirvÄá¹‡a.

With a single sound, causing all sentient beings to rejoice, demonstrating the great nirvÄá¹‡a without ceasing the practices of bodhisattvas, showing sentient beings the ground of great wisdom, causing them to know that all phenomena are false and deceptive.

Because of the great wisdom, great spiritual powers, and mastery of transformation, they give rise to such great vows, vast like the nature of phenomena, ultimate like space, exhausting the future, exhausting all kalpas, attaining Buddhahood, seeking great wisdom, great spiritual powers, and so forth, without rest.
Buddha's disciples!
Bodhisattvas dwelling on the ground of joy, with ten vows as the foremost, give rise to such a hundred thousand asaá¹ƒkhyeya great vows.
He gave rise to this vow with ten inexhaustible dharmas and diligently practiced with vigor to fulfill this vow.
What are the ten?

First, sentient beings are inexhaustible; second, the world is inexhaustible; third, space is inexhaustible; fourth, the nature of dharmas is inexhaustible; fifth, nirvana is inexhaustible; sixth, the appearance of buddhas in the world is inexhaustible; seventh, the wisdom of all buddhas is inexhaustible; eighth, mental objects are inexhaustible; ninth, the arising of wisdom is inexhaustible; tenth, the seeds of worldly paths, the seeds of the path of dharmas, and the seeds of the wisdom path are inexhaustible.
As sentient beings are inexhaustible, so too is my vow inexhaustible.

As the world is inexhaustible, as space is inexhaustible, as the nature of dharmas is inexhaustible, as nirvana is inexhaustible, as the appearance of buddhas in the world is inexhaustible, as the wisdom of all buddhas is inexhaustible, as mental objects are inexhaustible, as the arising of wisdom is inexhaustible, and as the seeds of the path are inexhaustible, so too is my vow inexhaustible.

Yet sentient beings are truly inexhaustible, the world, space, the nature of dharmas, nirvana, the appearance of Buddhas, the wisdom of all Buddhas, the wisdom of mind-born knowledge, and the seeds of the path are truly inexhaustible, and my vows and merits are also inexhaustible.
Buddha's disciples!

If bodhisattvas definitely make these great vows, they will attain a beneficial mind, a soft mind, a well-disciplined mind, a good mind, a tranquil mind, a harmonious mind, a straightforward mind, an undisturbed mind, an unharming mind, and an untroubled mind.
In this way, they will become believers, with a joyful mind and the characteristics of faith, distinguishing merits and virtues.

They believe in the path that all Buddhas have originally practiced, believe in practicing the pÄramitÄs and thereby attaining growth, believe in skillfully entering the grounds and attaining the supreme merits, believe in attaining the ten powers of a Buddha, believe in perfecting the four forms of fearlessness, believe that the unique dharmas of the Buddha are indestructible, believe that the dharmas of the Buddhas are inconceivable, believe that the power of the TathÄgatas is without middle or end, believe in the immeasurable approach of the TathÄgatas, and believe that the fruition of causes and conditions is produced.
In brief, they believe in the bodhisattvas' universal practice of the Buddhas' merits, wisdom, and majestic spiritual power, and so forth.
Children of the Buddhas!
The bodhisattvas think like this:

'The true Dharma of the Buddhas is like this profound, like this devoid of characteristics, like this extinguished, like this empty, like this signless, like this wishless, like this undefiled, like this immeasurable, like this vast, like this difficult to destroy.

Yet ordinary beings fall into wrong views, their wisdom eye obscured by ignorance and delusion, always erecting the banner of arrogance, falling into the net of craving, conforming to flattery, and harboring stinginess and jealousy, creating the causes and conditions for rebirth in their next life.

They accumulate much greed, anger, and delusion, give rise to heavy karma, and the fierce wind of resentment blows the fire of their sinful mind, always causing it to blaze. Whatever they do is associated with perversion.

The streams of desire, existence, ignorance, and views continue, giving rise to the seeds of mind, thought, and consciousness, producing the sprouts of suffering and distress in the three realms and on the grounds, namely:
Name and form come together and increase the six sense bases;ğŸ”½The external objects corresponding to the sense bases give rise to contact;
Because of contact, various feelings arise;ğŸ”½Because of deeply enjoying feelings, craving arises;
Because craving increases, grasping arises;
Because grasping increases, future existence arises again;
There are causes and conditions, so there is birth, old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress.

In this way, the accumulation of causes and conditions gives rise to the mass of suffering. Sentient beings experience various kinds of suffering and distress. In this, there is no self, no possession of a self, no doer, no experiencer, no knower, like grass, trees, tiles, and stones, or like a shadow.
Foolish ordinary beings are pitiable. They do not know, do not understand, and experience suffering and distress.
The Bodhisattva, seeing that sentient beings cannot escape from suffering in this way, immediately gives rise to the wisdom of great compassion:
'These sentient beings, we should save them.'
And wishing to cause them to abide in the bliss of the ultimate Buddha Way, he immediately gives rise to the wisdom of great kindness.

The Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva, in accordance with this Dharma of great kindness and compassion, with a profound and wonderful mind abides in the first ground, not being stingy or miserly with any possessions.
In order to respect the great and wondrous wisdom of the buddhas, they study and practice great relinquishment. At that time, they are able to give away all objects that can be given, namely:

grains, wheat, storehouses, gold, silver, maá¹‡i jewels, agate, lapis lazuli, coral, amber, conch shells, necklaces, ornaments for adorning the body, various precious treasures, as well as elephants, horses, carriages, palanquins, people, servants, retinue, countries, cities, villages, houses, gardens, forests, places for recreation, wives, children, sons, and all that is loved. They give all of these away, as well as their heads, eyes, ears, nose, limbs, hands, and feet, giving their entire body. Because they deeply cherish the wisdom of the buddhas, they do not begrudge anything. Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas dwelling in the first ground are able to practice great relinquishment.

Because this bodhisattva, with a mind of great compassion and great equanimity, saves all sentient beings, he diligently seeks the supreme benefits of the world and transcendence, his mind without weariness. Therefore, the bodhisattva gives rise to the merit of being indefatigable.
He is able to understand the various scriptures by himself, and therefore gives rise to the merit of knowing the scriptures.

Having attained this wisdom of knowing the scriptures, he is well able to discern what should be done and what should not be done, and acts appropriately towards sentient beings of superior, middling, and inferior capacities. He benefits those who come to rely on him to the best of his ability. Therefore, the bodhisattva gives rise to the merit of worldly wisdom.

Having attained the merit of worldly wisdom, he knows the proper time and proper measure, and is adorned with a sense of shame and dishonor. He cultivates the path of benefiting himself and others, and therefore gives rise to the merit of a sense of shame and dishonor.
He diligently practices within these meritorious activities, his mind without indolence or retreat. This is the merit of indefatigable diligence, and he immediately attains the power of endurance;
Having attained the power of endurance, they diligently make offerings to the buddhas and practice as the buddhas teach.
Children of the buddhas!
These bodhisattvas fully understand the arising of such pure ground dharmas, namely:

faith, kindness, compassion, equanimity, indefatigability, knowledge of various scriptures, skillful understanding of worldly dharmas, shame, the power of endurance, making offerings to the buddhas, and practicing as taught.
Moreover, these bodhisattvas dwelling in the ground of joy, due to their vows, extensively see many buddhas, hundreds, thousands, and millions of nayutas of buddhas.

When the bodhisattvas see the buddhas, their minds are greatly joyful, and with deep love and respect, they make offerings to the buddhas and the saá¹…gha with the requisites enjoyed by bodhisattvas, and with this merit they all dedicate it to supreme, perfect enlightenment.

Because this bodhisattva, by making offerings to the buddhas, gives rise to the Dharma of teaching and transforming sentient beings, and mostly uses the two kinds of embracing to embrace sentient beings - namely, giving and kind speech - but the methods of the latter two kinds of embracing are only practiced with the power of faith and understanding, and are not yet well penetrated.

This bodhisattva, following the offerings made to the buddhas and the teaching and transforming of sentient beings, is able to practice and uphold the pure Dharma of the stages. In this way, all these merits naturally turn towards sarvajÃ±a, becoming even more radiant and useful.
It is like, Buddha's disciples!
A goldsmith refines gold, and according to the fire's power, it becomes pliable and usable, increasing in radiance.

In the same way, the bodhisattva, following the offerings made to the buddhas, the teaching and transforming of sentient beings, and the practice and upholding of the pure Dharmas of the stages, all these merits naturally turn towards sarvajÃ±a, becoming even more radiant and useful as one wishes.
Moreover, all you disciples!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should, in the first ground, inquire from Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, and good and virtuous friends about the characteristics and fruits of attainment, and should not be discouraged or give up the Dharma of perfecting the grounds.ğŸ”½This Bodhisattva, dwelling in the first ground, should inquire from Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, and good and virtuous friends about the characteristics and fruits of attainment in the second ground, and should not be satisfied with just that;

in the same way, he should inquire about the characteristics and fruits of attainment in the third, fourth, fifth, sixth, seventh, eighth, ninth, and tenth grounds, and should inquire from Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, and good and virtuous friends about the Dharma of perfecting the ten grounds, and should not be discouraged or give up.

This bodhisattva should fully understand the methods of going against and following the stages, fully understand the formation and destruction of the stages, fully understand the characteristics, causes, and effects of the stages, fully understand the attainment and abandonment of the stages, fully understand the aspects of the pure practices of the stages, fully understand the practices from one stage to another stage, fully understand the proper and improper of the stages, fully understand the turning and abiding of the stages, fully understand the differences in the initial and later events of the stages, fully understand the signs of non-retrogression in the stages, and so forth, up to fully understanding the pure stage dharmas of all bodhisattvas and fully understanding the entry into the stage of the TathÄgata's wisdom.
Children of the buddhas!

In this way, the bodhisattvas fully understand the characteristics of the stages - from the stage of not yet generating the mind up to the tenth stage - and know them without obstruction. Because they attain the wisdom and light of the stages, they are able to attain the wisdom and light of the buddhas.
Children of the buddhas!
It is like a great caravan leader who, with many merchants, wishes to go to a great city. He should first ask about the road, the faults of turning back, and the benefits and harms on the road.

Before setting out, he should know the places to stay along the way, and so on, and know well how to reach that city. He can use wisdom to contemplate and calculate, and with all the necessary provisions, he can lead the people to the great city without any lack or shortage. In the dangerous road, he can avoid all difficulties and dangers, and both himself and the people will be free from worries and troubles.
Buddha's disciples!

The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva is also like this. Abiding in the first ground, he well knows the Dharma of going against and following the various grounds, and so on, up to well knowing the Dharma of entering the TathÄgata's ground of purifying all bodhisattvas.

At that time, the Bodhisattva, having accumulated the provisions of great merit and wisdom, became the caravan leader for sentient beings, teaching them as appropriate, enabling them to escape the dangerous and evil realms of birth and death, showing them the path of peace and security, and even enabling them to abide in the great city of omniscient wisdom without any afflictions.
Therefore, all Buddha's disciples!
The Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva should always be tireless in mind, diligently cultivating the fundamental practices of the stages, and even skillfully knowing how to enter the TathÄgata's stage of wisdom.
All Buddha's disciples!

This is called the brief explanation of the Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's entry into the stage of joy. The extensive explanation has immeasurable hundreds of thousands of myriads of koá¹­is of nayutas of matters.

The Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva abiding in this stage often becomes the king of JambudvÄ«pa, with great wealth and self-mastery, always protecting the true Dharma, able to attract sentient beings through generosity, skillfully removing the defilements of stinginess and greed in sentient beings, always practicing great giving without becoming impoverished.

All the merit and virtue created by good deeds - whether giving, kind speech, beneficial action, or cooperation - are all done without separating from the thought of the Buddha, without separating from the thought of the Dharma, without separating from the thought of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas as companions, without separating from the thought of the bodhisattva's practices, without separating from the thought of the perfections, without separating from the thought of the ten grounds, without separating from the thought of the powers, fearlessnesses, and unique qualities, up to without separating from the thought of fully perfecting omniscience.
Always give rise to this thought:

'I should be the foremost, the most excellent, the greatest, the most wonderful, the highest, the unsurpassed, the leader, the general, the teacher, the venerable one among all sentient beings, up to being the support for all sentient beings.'
Children of the buddhas!

If these bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas wish to abandon their homes and diligently practice, in an instant they will be able to abandon their homes, wives, and the five desires within the Buddha's teachings.

Having gone forth, if they diligently practice, in an instant they will attain a hundred samÄdhis, see a hundred buddhas, know the supernormal powers of a hundred buddhas, be able to shake a hundred buddha-lands, be able to fly past a hundred buddha-lands, be able to illuminate a hundred buddha-lands, be able to teach and transform the beings in a hundred buddha-lands, be able to abide for a hundred eons, be able to know the events of the past and future for a hundred eons, be able to skillfully enter a hundred Dharma gates, be able to transform their bodies into a hundred, and be able to manifest a hundred bodhisattvas in each body as their retinue. If they manifest by the power of their vows, they will surpass this number, with many hundreds of thousands of myriads of koá¹­is of nayutas that cannot be calculated or known.
At that time, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva Vajra Treasury, wanting to restate this meaning, spoke in verse:
If there are sentient beings who extensively cultivate wholesome roots,
Accomplish the pure dharmas, and draw near to the buddhas,
With the great power of pure faith, following the compassionate mind,
Such people can give rise to the immeasurable wisdom of the buddhas.
The omniscience of the buddhas, the immeasurable power of purity,
The power of endurance, firm and solid, accomplishing the buddhas' teachings.
With a compassionate mind, saving the world, purifying the buddha-lands,
Expounding and turning the wheel of the Dharma, giving rise to this unsurpassed vow.
In a single thought, knowing the three times, yet without any distinction,
The various distinctions of time are shown to the world.
In brief, it is seeking the merits of all buddhas to the end,
Giving rise to an expansive mind, vast like space.
With compassion and wisdom as the head, practicing in accord with skillful means,
With pure faith and a profound mind, their power is immeasurable.
Their minds are directed towards unobstructedness, and they do not follow the teachings of others.
They are equal to all Buddhas, and give rise to the great mind.
The children of the Buddhas should give rise to such a true mind,
And immediately leave the practices of ordinary beings, entering the practices of the Buddhas;
They immediately take birth in the family of the TathÄgatas, without anything to be criticized or despised.
They are the same as all Buddhas, and will certainly accomplish the unsurpassed path.
When they give rise to such a mind, they immediately attain the first ground,
And their mind cannot be moved, just like the king of mountains.
These Bodhisattvas then have the great joy manifest,
And their mind is always pure, able to receive great matters.
Their mind does not delight in disputes, and they do not enjoy troubling sentient beings.
They have no angry or resentful mind, and delight in shame, modesty, and respect.
Moreover, cultivating the practice of straightforward mind, guarding the various faculties,
Always thinking to save the world, thinking to seek the wisdom of the buddhas.
The mind gives rise to joy, thinking I shall attain this,
Attaining the ground of joy, one immediately transcends five fears:
Fear of not surviving, fear of death, and fear of bad reputation,
Fear of the three evil destinies, and fear of the awesome virtue of the great assembly.
Because of not being attached to self and what belongs to self,
These buddha-sons are far removed from all fears.
Always practicing the mind of loving-kindness and compassion, always having faith and respect,
Endowed with the merit of shame and conscience, increasing wholesome dharmas day and night.
Delighting in the true benefits of merit, not delighting in desires,
Whatever Dharma is heard, one is always able to contemplate it well.
Without any greedy and attached conduct, cutting off thoughts of gain and profit,
Always delighting in bodhi, single-mindedly seeking the Buddha's wisdom.
Practicing the pÄramitÄs, free from flattery and deceit,
In accordance with what is said, able to practice, abiding in true speech.
Not sullying the Buddha's family, not abandoning the bodhisattva's training,
Far from worldly affairs, delighting in benefiting the world.
Seeking good dharmas without satiety, diligent progress increasing,
Thus are the bodhisattvas, delighting in all merits,
And giving rise to great vows, seeking to see the buddhas,
Protecting the Dharma to the Buddha's place, practicing the bodhisattva's wondrous conduct,
Transforming all sentient beings, purifying all buddha-lands.
In my buddha-land, filled with great bodhisattvas,
The bodhisattvas have the same mind, seeing and hearing are all not empty.
In all minute particles, the buddhas attain buddhahood,
Giving rise to such immeasurable and boundless vows,
These vows are inexhaustible, like space, sentient beings,
The nature of phenomena, the world, nirvana, the appearance of buddhas, wisdom,
The mind's objects, the wisdom that arises from conditions, and seeds - my vows abide thus.
Having given rise to such great vows, the mind becomes soft and pliable,
Able to have faith in the Buddha's merits and contemplate sentient beings.
Knowing that they arise from causes and conditions, then the mind of compassion arises,
Immediately thinking, I shall save and deliver those suffering beings.
For the sake of these sentient beings, I shall practice various kinds of giving,
Namely, the most wonderful lands, the most excellent and precious treasures,
Elephants, horses, and carriages, retinues and people,
Heads, eyes, hands, and feet, flesh and skin - giving without regret.
Seeking various scriptures and treatises, their minds are never weary,
Understanding their meanings, they are able to follow the world.
With a sense of shame and acceptance, they gradually cause it to increase,
Able to make offerings to immeasurable buddhas with a respectful mind.
The wise ones, day and night, always practice in this way,
The roots of goodness become clear, just like refined gold.
The bodhisattvas dwelling in this stage are able to understand the ten abodes,
As they progress in practice, there are no obstructions.
It is like a caravan leader, wishing to benefit the merchants,
First inquiring about the dangerous and difficult matters on the road.
The bodhisattvas dwelling in the first stage should understand the practices of the stages,
Without obstructions, they are able to reach the stage of buddhahood.
Dwelling in this first stage, they often become kings of JambudvÄ«pa,
Well understanding all dharmas, always practicing with a compassionate mind.
In accordance with the Dharma, guiding and transforming, all give rise to faith and respect,
Encouraging them to practice giving, seeking the wisdom of the buddhas.
If bodhisattvas renounce their countries and go forth in the Buddha's teachings,
Diligent in practicing vigor, they will attain a hundred samÄdhis,
And see a hundred buddhas, shaking a hundred lands,
With light illuminating a hundred lands, flying through the air likewise,
Transforming the beings of a hundred lands, entering a hundred Dharma gates,
Remembering and understanding the events of a hundred eons, manifesting a hundred kinds of bodies,
Able to manifest with a hundred bodhisattvas as their retinue,
If using their vow power, surpassing this number is immeasurable.
Now clarifying the meaning of the first ground, only briefly explaining,
If wanting to explain in detail, even for a hundred million eons it would not be exhausted.
This is the first bodhisattva ground, called the ground of joy,
For the benefit of sentient beings, it has now been explained in detail.
All the assemblies of bodhisattvas, upon hearing the meaning of the higher grounds,
Their minds all became pure, and they rejoiced immeasurably.
Each one rose up in the sky from their seat,
And took off their own sublime upper robe to scatter over Vajra Treasury.
All of them exclaimed in praise, saying:
Excellent, Vajra Treasury!
With great wisdom and fearlessness, you skillfully expound the bodhisattva grounds.
The great being Moon of Liberation, knowing the pure minds of the assembly,
Desiring to hear about the characteristics of the second ground,
Then addressed Vajra Treasury, saying:
Great Wisdom One!
Please explain the characteristics of the second ground, all wish to hear.
At that time, Vajra Treasury Bodhisattva MahÄsattva said to Liberation Moon Bodhisattva:
Buddha's disciple!
If Bodhisattva MahÄsattvas have already perfected the first ground and wish to attain the second ground, they should give rise to ten states of mind.
What are the ten?

First, a pliable mind; second, a well-regulated mind; third, a mind capable of enduring; fourth, a good mind; fifth, a mind of tranquility; sixth, a sincere mind; seventh, an unadulterated mind; eighth, a mind free from greed and stinginess; ninth, a joyful mind; tenth, a magnanimous mind.
If Bodhisattva MahÄsattvas have already perfected the first ground and wish to attain the second ground, they should first give rise to these ten states of mind.
Buddha's disciples!

If Bodhisattvas wish to abide in this ground of freedom from defilements, they should, from the very beginning, refrain from all killing, abandon knives and sticks, be free from thoughts of anger and resentment, have a sense of shame and a sense of dishonor.

They give rise to a mind of loving-kindness and compassion towards all sentient beings, always seeking pleasant things. They do not even harm sentient beings with an evil mind, let alone with coarse and evil [actions].
They are free from all robbery and theft. Their possessions are always sufficient, and they do not destroy others' wealth.
If an object belongs to others, is being used by others, or is possessed by others, they do not take even a blade of grass or a leaf from it, let alone anything more.
They are free from sexual misconduct. They are content with their own wives and do not seek external desires or the wives of others.
They do not even give rise to thoughts [of desire], let alone engage in [sexual activity].
They are free from false speech. They always speak truthfully, truthfully, factually, and in accordance with reality. They do not create hateful false speech;
even in dreams they do not speak falsely, let alone intentionally tell lies.

They are free from divisive speech. They have no intention to create divisions. What they hear from this person they do not tell to another, and what they hear from that person they do not tell to this person. Among those who quarrel and disperse, they always delight in reconciliation.

They avoid harsh speech, and abandon all words that are coarse, vulgar, painful, and hateful, as well as those that cause others to be angry, fearful, or anxious, and that are unloved and displeasing, destroying one's own body and that of others.

They speak words that are very delightful, beautiful to the ear, able to transform the minds of others, gentle and complete, loved by many, and able to bring joy and pleasure to others, always speaking such words.

They avoid idle chatter, always guarding themselves, speaking only what should be said or not said, always speaking words that are timely, true, beneficial, in accord with the Dharma, measured, and not for the sake of amusement or entertainment, not even engaging in idle chatter in jest, let alone intentionally.ğŸ”½They are not greedy for others' possessions, and do not think:
'I should take that which belongs to others, which others desire and use.'
They are free from the mind of anger, harm, resentment, and oppressive heat, and always seek good things for sentient beings, with a mind of love, moisture, benefit, and compassion.

They are free from divination, practice right views, deeply believe in the causes and conditions of sin and merit, are free from flattery, sincerely believe in the Three Jewels, and give rise to a determined mind.
The bodhisattva thus always protects the good path and thinks like this:
'Sentient beings who fall into the evil paths all do so due to the causes and conditions of the ten unwholesome paths of action.
I should now abide by the ten wholesome dharmas myself, and also explain the wholesome dharmas to others and show them the place of right practice.
Why is it so?
If a person does not practice goodness themselves, it is impossible for them to explain the Dharma to others and cause them to abide in goodness.'
Moreover, the bodhisattva further deeply contemplates:
'Due to the causes and conditions of engaging in the ten unwholesome paths of action, one will fall into the hells, the realm of animals, or the realm of hungry ghosts;
Because of the causes and conditions of practicing the ten wholesome deeds, one is reborn in the human realm, up to the highest heaven.
Moreover, these ten wholesome deeds are practiced in conjunction with wisdom.

Those whose minds are weak and inferior, who delight in few merits and are fearful of the three realms with a thin mind of great compassion, will attain the vehicle of the hearers by listening to the Dharma from others.

There are also people who practice these ten wholesome deeds, but do not listen to others, and naturally understand them. They are unable to fully possess the power of great compassion and skillful means, but are able to deeply penetrate the Dharma of dependent origination and attain the vehicle of the pratyekabuddhas.
There are also people who practice these ten wholesome deeds, purely and completely, with a mind that is vast and boundless.

Among sentient beings, they give rise to great kindness, compassion, and the power of skillful means, with firm aspirations - because they do not abandon any sentient beings, seek the great wisdom of the Buddha, purify the various stages of the bodhisattvas, and are able to purify the perfections, they are able to enter the profound and vast practices.

Moreover, it can purify the practice of the ten wholesome deeds, and even attain the ten powers of the Buddha, the four fearlessnesses, the four unobstructed understandings, great compassion, and even be fully endowed with omniscience and gather all the Buddha's teachings.
Therefore, we should practice the ten wholesome deeds and always seek all wisdom.
The bodhisattva further contemplates:
'These ten unwholesome deeds, the highest lead to the causes for hell, the middling lead to the causes for the animal realm, and the lowest lead to the causes for the hungry ghost realm.
Among them, the sin of killing can cause sentient beings to fall into hell, the animal realm, or the hungry ghost realm, and if reborn among humans, they will obtain two kinds of karmic retribution:
First, a short lifespan; second, many illnesses.
